repnme.cdata!:
Republic of Burundi - Public Works and
            Employment Creation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Public Works and
            Employment Creation Project for Burundi are as follows:
            outcome was satisfactory, risk to the development outcome
            was moderate, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was rated as satisfactory. Some of the
            lessons learned included: 1) the delegated contract
            management arrangement is well-suited to mitigating capacity
            constraints in a post-conflict environment. Showing peace
            dividends in a post-conflict environment requires swift
            implementation of programs while ensuring that fiduciary
            requirements are met. Delegated contract management
            arrangements using streamlined and transparent procurement
            procedures and faster payment methods of contractors have
            proved to be very efficient in delivering quick results on
            the ground ; 2) demand-driven selection through
            participatory arrangements of communities'
            infrastructure needs is most suited to address social
            cohesion and sustainability of services in post-conflict
            environments. With a social fabric very fragmented as a
            result of years of conflict and the persistent perception of
            Government unfairness in allocating public resources, a
            demand-based approach to the selection and financing of
            community infrastructure needs is appropriate to ensure
            transparency in resource allocation and strengthened social
            cohesion, while at the same time improving the prospects for
            sustainable operation of financed facilities. However, a
            proper mechanism to ensure equitable distribution of
            sub-projects is needed to avoid project concentration in the
            capital city and a few major urban centers; and 3) short
            term employment creation is critical in post-conflict
            environments. Public works projects using labor-intensive
            technologies can address high unemployment levels and also
            the revenue-generating needs of conflict-affected groups
            such as single women, ex-combatants, returnees and refugees.

repnme.cdata!:
Burundi - Public Works and Employment
            Creation Project : Inspection Panel request for inspection

abstracts.cdata!:
The request for Inspection was submitted
            by AFROPROCA - Association pour la Formation, la Production
            des ouvrages de carrieres et la lutte contre le SIDA sur les
            chantiers a haute intensite de main d'oeuvre - and its
            legal representatives. The requesters believe that their
            rights and interests have been harmed because of violations
            of Bank Policies and Procedures, namely concerning project
            supervision (OP/BP 13.05), concerning procurement (OP/BP
            11.00), and on violations of Bank guidelines on procurement
            under Bank loans and credits, and, concerning the selection,
            and employment of consultants by Bank Borrowers. The
            requesters also assert that on several occasions they
            informed, and exchanged correspondence with the Bank, and
            the Government of Burundi, finding no attempt to remedy the
            situation. Requesters consider Bank's actions and
            omissions, to be contrary to its Policies and Procedures,
            and therefore request the Panel to recommend an investigation.

repnme.cdata!:
Burundi - Public Works and Employment
            Creation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Public Works and Employment Creation
            Project will contribute to the peace process, and
            reconstruction of Burundi, through generation of productive,
            labor-intensive employment. The components will: 1) finance
            subprojects for the rehabilitation, and construction of
            basic infrastructure at municipalities' request,
            namely, roads, markets, drainage, health centers,
            anti-erosion structures, schools, and water supply,
            including social infrastructure. The financial, and
            operational capabilities of the Agence d'Execution des
            Travaux d'Interet Public (AGETIP) will be strengthened,
            by financing equipment, and operating costs, technical
            assistance (TA) and training provision; 2) establish a
            Technical Secretariat (TS) at the Ministry of Public Works,
            responsible of providing TA, advisory services, and training
            to municipalities in subproject identification, programming,
            operation and maintenance. The TS will also be responsible
            for disseminating information through communication
            campaigns on subproject eligibility criteria; 3) support the
            prevention of HIV/AIDS epidemic, to include a community
            information and education program, based on existing
            frameworks, implemented under the responsibility of the TS,
            in partnership with UNAIDS, Red Cross, and non-governmental
            organizations, and a study on a multi-sectoral HIV/AIDS
            program; and, 4) include project monitoring, supporting
            studies, consultants/auditors.

repnme.cdata!:
Burundi - Projet des Travaux Publics et de
            Creation d'Emplois : evaluation environnementale

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment (EA)
            outlines the methodology to be followed regarding potential
            environmental impacts, resulting from the implementation of
            the Public Works and Employment Creation Project. It
            analyzes the institutional, judicial and regulatory
            framework, as it relates to environmental management in
            Burundi, followed by a description of negative environmental
            effects, and measures to minimize those effects. It is
            expected that soil erosion, and sedimentation will occur, as
            well as flooding. As a result, water discharges will
            increase, aggravated by poor drainage systems, thus
            affecting health, and hygienic aspects among the population.
            However, it is expected that the new long lasting roads will
            improve traffic and transportation, and prod economic
            growth, through increased commercial private initiatives
            promoting local products, thus outweighing negative impacts.
            Measures to mitigate negative impacts include: soil erosion
            protection, taking into account natural slopes to
            appropriately discharge rain waters, and in turn prevent
            flooding, and, installation of sewerage collectors for
            wastewater discharges, with special attention to the quality
            of materials to be utilized; re-vegetation, and
            re-forestation will be implemented, to control river
            flooding as needed; aquatic species will be introduced for
            reproduction as needed, while river flows will be protected
            by forbidding waste disposals, and swimming; traffic signals
            will be installed, and, periodic inspections will be
            conducted on construction sites to enforce environmental measures.
